awd_titl_txt: Dissertation Research:  Testing the effects of large mammalian herbivores on savanna dynamics and community structure with regional- and continent-scale natural experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to determine how population declines of large mammalian herbivores (e.g., elephants, wildebeest, buffalo, antelopes, and zebra) affect African savanna habitats. Small-scale experimental studies have shown that because these large herbivores consume huge quantities of plant material, losing these species is likely to profoundly affect vegetation. The researchers will test how population declines and consequent changes in the frequency of two types of large herbivore-plant interactions alter savanna vegetation. In order to determine  whether tree species reliant on large-mammal seed dispersal have declined in abundance, the  research team will conduct fieldwork in Gorongosa National Park, Mozambique, where poaching during the 1977-1992 civil war nearly eliminated all large mammals. Second, by analyzing historical and modern satellite imagery, the researchers will test whether recent, human-driven declines in elephant populations across African protected areas lead to increased tree cover and possibly consequent threats to species adapted to historically sparse tree cover in African savannas. Elephants are particularly important savanna herbivores because they topple trees, potentially maintaining open savanna habitats. Many U.S. ecosystems have also experienced recent, dramatic changes in mammalian herbivore pressure as deer populations have exploded, and this research will advance our understanding of ecosystem responses to changed herbivory regimes. Project results will be incorporated into an undergraduate course on ecology and conservation. Results will be disseminated through scientific articles, blogs on park and affiliated websites, and online videos produced by the E.O. Wilson Biodiversity Foundation.

Vegetation structure and composition is shifting in savannas across Africa due to altered fire regimes and climate change, but the extent to which declining herbivore populations are responsible for changing vegetation is unclear. Fieldwork in Gorongosa will include comparisons of vegetation in woodland patches that recruited prior to and since large mammal declines to test whether new woodland communities are relatively devoid of mammal-dispersed plants. This pattern is known from tropical forests where seed-dispersing mammals have declined, but the extent to which savanna trees depend on large mammals for dispersal is unknown. To test support for the hypothesis that recent declines in elephant populations lead to increased savanna tree cover, the researchers will build statistical models predicting changes in remotely sensed tree cover for African parks from published estimates of elephant density along with remotely sensed fire and rainfall data.

por.por_cntn:
We aimed to better understand how large mammalian herbivores (e.g., elephants, buffalo, wildebeest, and various antelope species) affect the structure of African savannas (tree abundance, plant and animal species composition). Previously, more effort was focused on the influences of large predators and abiotic factors (fire and rainfall). However, ecosystem management in the face of ongoing wildlife declines in Africa necessitate better knowledge of these species’ impacts on the ecosystems from which they are disappearing. 

 We first studied vegetation responses to the near-elimination of large mammalian herbivores from an entire savanna. We worked in Gorongosa National Park, Mozambique (3300 km2) where >95% of the mammals were killed for food or ivory during the country’s 1977-1992 civil war. Some of these herbivores (notably elephants) are browsers, consuming primarily woody plants; others (esp. wildebeest and buffalo in Gorongosa) are grazers and eat mainly grass. Browser declines might have increased tree cover, or grazer removal might have increased open areas by leaving grass to fuel fires. Comparing tree cover from recently declassified 1977 C.I.A. satellite imagery and recent commercial images, we determined that browser removal had a stronger impact:  tree cover increased park-wide by 34%, a potentially negative outcome for savanna plants and the mammals now being restored in Gorongosa, which are adapted to a mix of open and wooded habitats. 

Large mammalian herbivores can impact animals, too. For instance, herbivory by an antelope makes less forage available to insect or rodent herbivores. Conversely, some species are facilitated by large herbivores; as one example, Kenyan dwarf geckos use crevices created when elephants damage trees. To determine the net directional effects of large herbivores on other animals, we extracted data on the strength of these effects from the published literature. To predict where such effects might be strongest, we located each study on a global map of net primary productivity, a proxy for plant growth rates. We expected productivity might predict the strength of herbivore effects on other animals because (1) plants are better-defended through spines and toxins in less productive habitats, potentially reducing herbivory and its consequences for other animals; and (2) faster regrowth of plants in higher-productivity areas might reduce the effects of herbivory. Globally, the average effect of large herbivores on other animals was negative, likely due primarily to competition and to degradation of vegetation used as habitat by smaller species. These effects were weaker in higher-productivity ecosystems, suggesting the effects of large mammal declines might be strongest in lower-productivity ecosystems (dry savannas and deserts).

We investigated the feedbacks from vegetation structure and other habitat characteristics to large herbivores in Gorongosa using hourly GPS data for individuals of three species of browsing antelope—bushbuck, nyala, and kudu—to understand how they are selecting habitat. Though closely related, the species differ in body size and consequently in the biology that determines how they should select habitat. Analysis is ongoing, but kudu, the largest species and therefore the one most invulnerable to predation and able to digest higher proportions of low-quality forage, selected for low tree-cover areas with relatively frequent fires; nyala and bushbuck, more vulnerable to predators and more strictly browsers of high-quality tree and shrub leaves, preferred woodier habitats that burned less often. All three species also selected for longer fire return intervals and for areas closer to termite mounds (which rarely burn and so provide abundant forage, shade, and cover from predators), though they did so with decreasing strength relative to increasing body size. 

 Finally, we investigated the association between armed conflict and large mammal population declines across Africa, as this is one factor that may initiate the kinds of herbivore-driven changes that we document. Conflict erodes conservation efforts and exacerbates poverty, potentially driving increased poaching. Indeed, mammal populations in 121 parks in 19 African countries tended to decline in areas experiencing at least one year of conflict per decade between 1946-2010, and more frequent conflict was associated with stronger declines. This analysis provides the first synthetic, quantitative look at war’s impact on wildlife.

We presented our research to U.S. high school and undergraduate students, including three inner-city science classes in a school where over 80% of students are English language learners, and to a group of outstanding high school science students in Washington, D.C. One PhD. student and five undergraduates received training in field ecology and statistical analysis. We promoted sustainable economic activity in Gorongosa through funds paid for park services, and by training local scientific interns and field assistants. These jobs are rare in a country with little scientific infrastructure. Further, we filmed short videos on our research in the park and these were disseminated online through the E.O. Wilson Biodiversity Foundation and National Geographic along with a blog about our research. Finally, we helped design the park’s new state-of-the-art research center, a first-of-its-kind in Mozambique.
